Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
~ Chapter 4 — A primer on bee morphology

v [updated 6/28/2022]

~ In order to use the keys in this book effectively, it is important to become familiar with

~ the morphology of bees and the terms used to describe morphological features. With that goal in

iJ mind, we present below an overview of bee morphology and an introduction to the terms that are
used throughout the keys. We follow the terminology used in Michener (2007), which is based

~ on morphological studies of bees that date back to Michener’s PhD thesis (Michener 1944).

~ Additional key papers on bee morphology include Urban (1967), Camargo et al. (1967),

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
wv Eickwort (1969), Stephen et al. (1969), and Brooks (1988). The illustrations in this chapter are
redrawn from Michener (1944 and 1965a) and Danforth (1996). For a detailed look at the

~ internal and external anatomy of the honeybee (Apis mellifera), see Snodgrass (1956). For a

~ comprehensive and modern overview of general insect morphology, see Beutel et al. (2014).

¥ BODY REGIONS

= Before diving into the details, let’s consider a basic question. What do we call the three

~ body regions in bees? For most insects, the body is divided into three distinct regions: head,

iy thorax, and abdomen. The abdomen houses the reproductive, digestive, and excretory organs.
The thorax houses the leg and flight muscles, and the head bears the sensory organs and

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
~ mouthparts. However, in most Hymenoptera (bees included), the thorax and abdomen have been

ad reconfigured to such an extent that we cannot use these same terms. In Apocrita (= Hymenoptera

- with a narrow waist), the first abdominal segment has become attached to the posterior region of
the thorax and the narrow “waist” is actually a constriction between abdominal segments | and 2.

9 Therefore, in Apocrita, we need to use slightly different terms. In Apocrita we refer to the
“mesosoma” (= thorax plus first abdominal segment, or “propodeum”; Fig. 13) and “metasoma”

~ (= remaining abdominal segments). Thus, in bees, we refer to the three body regions as head,

~ mesosoma, and metasoma. The head and mesosoma are complex structures and we will cover

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
= those below. The metasoma, by contrast, is fairly simple consisting of dorsal sclerites (terga)
paired with ventral sclerites (sterna) to form a tube enclosing the internal organs plus genitalia.

~ For use of the keys, it will be important to identify specific metasomal terga or sterna. To do so,

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
we number terga and sterna of the metasoma starting with metasomal segment 1. Therefore, the

first metasoma tergum is T1, the second T2, and so forth. The same is true for sterna: the first ~
metasomal sternum is S1, the second S2, and so forth [Fig. 19]. Make sure that you are ~
comfortable with identifying specific metasomal terga and sterna when you start using the keys. wi

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
The sexes in bees are often quite different from one ~
another, and in parts of the keys the sexes are treated atl
separately. To people familiar with bees, males and females ~
can be distinguished most rapidly based on the overall shape ww
of the body — males are typically more slender than females
and they often have longer antennae. Also, the presence of a ~
distinct scopa will distinguish females from males in many ~
groups (excluding brood parasites, bees that carry pollen v
internally, and queens of advanced eusocial species). Finally,
females have stings, and males have male genitalia [Fig. 20]; ~
but both are commonly retracted, and in some females the ~
sting is rudimentary. Other features may need to be examined ¥
to verify the sex of an individual, including the number of

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
antennal segments and the number of visible metasomal ~
segments. Males have 13 antennal segments (12 in Neopasites ~
and Holcopasites);, females have 12 [Fig. 10]. In addition, ~
males and females typically differ in the number of visible ws
metasomal segments. In males, we can usually count seven
visible metasomal terga, whereas in females we can usually ~
count only six [Fig. 19]. But keep in mind that the last ad
segment, which often bears a pygidial plate, can be hidden. In ed
female Halictinae, for example, T6 is often hidden beneath
T5, so females appear to have just five visible terga. Likewise, ~
in some male bees it is difficult to see T7 because it is largely, ”
or rarely wholly, hidden beneath T6. In addition, in males of ~
some groups (e.g., Osmiini) the segments are greatly

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
telescoped and retracted so that the visible terga and sterna ~
can be reduced to as few as four visible sterna and terga. ~
HEAD CAPSULE (Figs 2-4, 10)

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
The malar area [Fig. 2] is the space between the eye and the mandible; its length is the =
shortest distance from the eye to the mandible [Fig. 4]; the width of this area is the width of the —
base of the mandible. The foveae (singular: fovea) of the face [Fig. 2] and of the sides of the
second metasomal tergum (T2) are shallow depressions, usually black in color, with a texture ~
distinct from the surrounding cuticle, and variable in shape. The term orbit is often used for the ~
eye margin, inner orbit for the frontal or facial margin, and outer orbit for the genal margin. The ~
genal area is the region behind the eye and in front of the preoccipital ridge [Figs. 3 and 4]. The v
ridge surrounding the concave posterior surface of the head above and laterally is called the

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content: preoccipital ridge [Fig. 3]. A carina sometimes found on this ridge is the preoccipital carina. The ~

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
~ proboscidial fossa is the large, deep groove on the
~ underside of the head into which the proboscis
~ folds [Fig. 3].
MOUTHPARTS (Figs. 5-9)
~ Bee mouthparts consist of paired mandibles
~ for chewing and a proboscis that can fold and
¥ unfold for lapping and sucking nectar. For the
names of mandibular structures [Fig. 5], we usually
~ follow Michener and Fraser (1978). For simplicity
~ we often refer to preapical teeth on the upper
7 margin instead of teeth of the pollex. Other terms used herein are the condylar ridge, which
arises near the mandibular condyle and extends toward the apex of the mandible, and the outer
~ ridge, which is the next ridge above the condylar ridge on the outer surface of the mandible.

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
~ The bee proboscis is a complex structure formed from a fusion of the maxilla and labium,
we which together make up the “labiomaxillary complex.” The maxilla consists of paired cardines
(singular: cardo) that suspend the labiomaxillary complex from beneath the head capsule, the
~ stipes, blade-like galea (plural: galeae), and the maxillary palpus (plural: palpi) with up to six
~ segments [Figs. 6, 7]. Attached at the apex of the
hs cardines is the labium, which consists of the lorum,
e mentum, prementum, tongue-like glossa, and (typically)
four-segmented labial palpus [Fig. 6]. In Colletidae the
~ glossa is quite different from that of other bees [Fig. 8,
~ 9]. Rather than being slender and elongate, as in most
ka other bee families, the colletid glossa is short and

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
bilobed (sometimes referred to as “bifid”). This
~ modification of the glossa is related to the application of
a the thick, cellophane brood cell lining that characterizes
~ colletid bees (Batra 1980).
Bees can be divided into two broad categories
~ based on mouthpart morphology: short-tongued bees
~ (Andrenidae, Halictidae, Colletidae, Stenotritidae, and
~ Melittidae), in which the labial palpal segments are all
v similar in morphology (Fig. 8), and long-tongued bees
(Apidae and Megachilidae), in which the first two labial
~ palpal segments are slender and blade-like (Fig. 6).
~ Danforth et al. (2019) provide a more detailed
_ description of the proboscis and how it functions.
The proboscis is typically folded beneath the
~ head capsule, making it very difficult to distinguish

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
~ among the complex and interconnected elements.
~ However, if the mouthparts are pulled before pinning, while the specimen is still flexible, the
o individual elements can be easily recognized. In some cases, it is necessary to examine the
maxillary and labial palpi and to count the number of palpal segments (e.g., in certain Eucerini).
~ It can also be useful to be able to identify the blade-like, first two labial palpal segments in long-

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
tongued bees as a tool for knowing whether you are examining a short-tongued or long-tongued
bee. But this is by no means essential for using the keys to the genera. Chapter 11 (Key to the ~
Families of North and Central America), however, makes heavy use of mouthpart characters ~
because these characters are defining features of the bee families. sl
MESOSOMA (Figs. 11-18) ~
The mesosoma is a compact structure consisting of sclerites of the pro-, meso- and ~
metathoracic segments, which bear the legs and wings, and the first true abdominal segment, WJ
termed the propodeum [Figs. 13 and 14]. The prothorax in bees is represented primarily by the
large pronotum, which extends laterally and meets ventrally behind the forecoxae, forming a ~

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
tubelike structure. The pronotal lobe is a useful landmark, and its shape and location may be used ~
in generic identification. The mesothorax and metathorax bear the wings and the second and is
third pairs of legs. In dorsal view [Fig. 14], the mesothorax can be divided into four distinct
sclerites: the scutum, the scutellum, and paired axillae. Dorsally, the metathorax consists of a ~
single sclerite, the metanotum. Laterally [Fig. 13], the mesothorax is represented by the ~
mesepisternum, sometimes referred to as the mesopleuron. The mesepisternum is sometimes ~
divided by the pre-episternal groove into the pre-episternum (or pre-episternal area) and the rest
of the mesepisternum. The shape and location of the pre-episternal groove, the scrobal groove, ~

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
and the scrobe are often important in generic identification. The metepisternum (or metapleuron) ~
forms the lateral surface of the metathorax. The wing bases are located above the upper margins ~
of the mesepisternum and the metepisternum. Js
<a
~
The form and subdivisions of the propodeum are not easy to illustrate but are exceedingly ~
important for identification. Many bees have a pair of impressed lines on the propodeum, Ww
beginning near the anterior dorsolateral parts of the propodeum and extending downward and
posteromesially and nearly meeting in the propodeal pit [Fig. 149], a median depression of the ~
lower posterior surface. These lines, together with the anterior dorsal margin of the propodeum, ~

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
enclose the triangular area, or propodeal triangle [Fig. 149]. Morphologically, this triangle is the ww
metapostnotum (Brothers 1976). The shape of the propodeum as seen in profile is quite
independent of the triangle. The whole propodeum may be vertical or nearly so, dropping from ~
the posterior margin of the metanotum. In this case it is termed declivous. However, as in Fig. ~
13, there may be a more or less horizontal basal region. In Fig. 13 it is separated by a sharp line, ~

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
~ or carina, from the declivous posterior surface. When such is the case, the horizontal part is
~ called the basal zone, or basal area, of the propodeum [Fig. 13]. It is part of the propodeal
~ triangle. The term "basal area" is applicable even if no
es sharp line separates the horizontal from the vertical
surfaces. In some bees the two surfaces are continuously
~ rounded, one onto the other in a broad curving surface; in
~ that case the term “basal area” is not definable unless there
~ is distinctive surface sculpturing.

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
Wings are illustrated, and the veins labeled, in
~ Figs. 15 and 16, using a modified Comstock and Needham
~ system. Because the homologies of the veins are not very
~ certain, as well as because some comparable-looking veins
- have very different morphological names, it has seemed

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
best to continue the use of some terms that are
~ morphologically noncommittal for certain cells and veins
ad heavily used in taxonomy. The names of cells and certain
e noncommittal names for veins are shown in Figs. 17 and
18.
~ Of special importance are three veins that all look
~ like crossveins: the second abscissa of Rs (or first
~ transverse cubital), first r-m (or second transverse cubital),
¥ and second r-m (or third transverse cubital), to use the
Comstock and Needham system. These veins help to
~ define the submarginal cells, which are usually either
~ three or two in number. It is important to note that
- submarginal cells can be variable within species. While
the vast majority of individuals within a species exhibit

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
~ the “typical” wing venation pattern for that species, there
~ are developmental anomalies that can result in non-
ww typical patterns of wing venation. Scarpulla (2018)
identified a number of such wing vein anomalies in
~ species of Colletidae, Andrenidae, Halictidae and
~ Apidae. These wing vein anomalies are commonly
~ expressed as a loss of the second transverse cubital vein
o in which a bee species that typically has three
submarginal cells instead has two. In some cases individuals can have normal wing venation on
~ one side of the body and non-typical wing venation on the other. If you suspect you have a
~ specimen with such a wing vein anomaly, the best solution is to compare it to other individuals
= of the same species to verify what is the “normal” pattern.

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
Wings are described as though spread, so that the direction toward the costal margin
~ (where the stigma is in the forewing) is called anterior; toward the wing apex, distal. To save
~ space, the word stigma is used in place of pterostigma [Fig. 15].
~ The jugal and vannal lobes of the hind wing are both measured from the wing base to the
v apices of the lobes. Thus, on Fig. 18 one might say that the jugal lobe is about two-thirds as long

as the vannal.

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
Some authorities advocate a system for identifying parts of legs that assumes that all legs ~
are pulled out laterally at right angles to the long axis of the body. Although we appreciate the ~
logic of that system, we follow the more traditional system in which the legs are considered to be ~
in their normal positions. Thus, we consider the corbicula of Apidae [Fig. 22] to be on the outer, eis
not the anterior, surface of the hind tibia, and we consider the two hind tibial spurs to be outer
and inner, not anterior and posterior. ~

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
The tibial spurs are the movable inferior apical spurs on the tibiae; the tibial spines are ”
immovable, sharp, superior, apical projections, usually small in size, found in some bees (see ~
Fig. 11 and Michener 1944). Description of the tibial spurs is important in many bees; this is ws
especially so of the inner hind tibial spur. This spur usually has two toothed margins. It is the
inner one that is commonly elaborated in various ways. It may be finely or coarsely serrate. ~
Following custom, we have described this margin as ciliate if it has slender, almost hairlike ~
projections (usually numerous), although in many cases the appearance is like that of a fine ¥
comb. Also following custom, we have described a spur as pectinate if its inner margin is

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
produced into a few long, coarse, often blunt projections [Fig. 154], even though the number of ~
such projections is in some cases reduced to only two or three. ~

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
The basitibial plate is a plate on the outer side of the ead
base of the hind tibia of many bees [Figs. 11, 174, and 175],
presumably important for support as bees move up or down we
their burrows in the soil. Commonly it is surrounded by a ~
carina or a sharp line of some sort and has vestiture (if any) —
different from that of adjacent regions, but it may be ws
indicated only by a series of tubercles, or even by a single
tubercle, and in some cases (as in Xvlocopa) its apex is ~
represented by a structure near the middle of the tibia. ~

On the inner surface of the hind tibia of most bees is w
an area of variable size covered with hairs of uniform length,
usually blunt or briefly bifid. These are called keirotrichia. ~

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
Between the tarsal claws there is often a protruding, ~
pad-like arolium (plural: arolia) [Fig. 12]. The arolium can Y
be lacking in some taxa, such as Megachile, Ptilothrix,

Euglossini, and Centridini. ~

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
The scopa (plural: scopae) is the pollen-carrying ~
brush of hairs. If such hairs surround a space in which pollen ~
is carried, they are said to form a corbicula. The best known w
corbicula is on the outer side of the hind tibia of Apidae, but
other corbiculae are on the underside of the hind femur of Andrenidae, Halictidae, Colletidae, ~
and others and on the side of the propodeum of many species of Andrena. In most bees the scopa bad
is on the hind legs, but in Megachilidae and some others it is on the underside of the metasoma. ww
Scopae are, of course, found only on nonparasitic females; in the keys, we do not state this fact
in every case. Scopae are absent in parasitic bees, in all male bees, in queens of highly social ~
bees, and in Hylaeus. teal

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
~ METASOMA (Figs. 19-22)
~ Each metasomal tergum or sternum (except for the anteriormost and the reduced apical
v ones) consists of a plate commonly marked by some transverse lines, as follows: (1) Across the
anterior margin, always completely hidden in the intact metasoma, is the antecosta. (2) Basal to
~ the middle of each plate is another transverse line, the gradulus (plural: graduli; Fig. 19). The
» ends of the tergal graduli, unless bent strongly to the rear, are usually near the spiracles. If bent
~ strongly to the rear, the resultant longitudinal lines are called lateral parts or lateral arms of the
graduli or, if carinate, lateral gradular carinae. The area anterior to the gradulus is usually at a

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
~ slightly higher level than that posterior to it, so that the gradulus is like a minute step. The
~ elevated, pre-gradular area provides a smooth surface for the anterior tergum or sternum to move
~ across as the metasoma moves and changes shape. The graduli are often concealed on the intact
- metasoma but, especially on the second tergum and sternum, are sometimes exposed. (3) Near
the posterior margin of each tergum and sternum is usually another transverse line, the
~ premarginal line, separating the posterior marginal area from the rest of the sclerite. This area is
w often depressed but in other cases differs only in sculpturing from the area basal to it.
we The pygidial plate [Fig. 19] is a usually flat plate, commonly surrounded by a carina or a

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
line and in some cases produced as an apical projection, on T6 of females or T7 of males. The
~ prepygidial fimbria is a dense band of hairs across the apex of T5 of females. It is conspicuously
~ different from, usually denser than, the apical hair bands or fasciae of preceding terga. Dense
~ hairs on T6 of females, on each side of the pygidial plate, constitute the pygidial fimbria [Fig.
ko 19].
~ The genital capsule [Fig. 20] as well as S7 and S8
¥ [Figs. 21, 22] of male bees exhibit many diagnostic characters
and may be dissected out for study (in fact, for some groups,
~ species-level identifications may require examination of male
~~ S7, S8 or the genital capsule). In some groups the sixth, fifth,
~ and even the fourth sterna are also hidden and modified. On a

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
freshly relaxed specimen it is usually possible to reach between the apical exposed tergum and
~ sternum and, with a hooked needle, pull out the genitalia and hidden sterna. In most cases such

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
~~
dissection is not difficult, but in the Megachilidae the numerous hidden sterna are firmly
connected to one another and to the terga laterally and are often delicate medially, so that ~
successful dissection may be difficult. Beginners should start with other groups. Y
For gross observations, sterna and genitalia may be preserved dry, glued to a card on the Ww
pin with the specimen. For more detailed study, they should be immersed in a solution of 10%
sodium or potassium hydroxide to remove the muscle tissue, then washed in water, and placed
for study in glycerin, and transferred for preservation to microvials, kept with the specimen by ~
running the pin through the stopper. Preservation on slides has the disadvantage of making side ww

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
views impossible, as well as crushing the genitalia, which are often quite thick. Y

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
~ Chapter 12 -- Notes on the genera

~ [updated 07/08/22 BND JLN]

ww The notes below are intended to supplement the keys in that they should help the user decide
whether they have successfully identified a specimen to genus. The notes are organized

~ according to the classification of bee genera presented in Table 2-1. The brief family

baad characterizations, as well as the “Key to the Families,” are probably accurate for our area but not

w necessarily worldwide. For a worldwide treatment of genera, see Michener (2007).

~ DESCRIPTIVE TERMS. For each genus, there are comments on appearance and sometimes on

~ distinguishing features other than those noted in the keys. General body shape is described in

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
w terms (listed below) such that with a single word a person who knows a few common bee genera

oe can get an idea of what an unknown genus looks like. Body forms are best appreciated in dorsal
view. Additional comments on color and pilosity are added to the descriptions below, where

~ useful.

ww andreniform—body form of Andrena [Figs. 421-424], Halictus [Figs. 439 and 440], or Colletes

v [Fig. 417]. Male often more slender, with more parallel-sided metasoma, than female.

~ anthophoriform—body form of Anthophora [Figs. 473 and 474]. Robust, with head and

w mesosoma hairy, enhancing the aspect of robustness; metasoma beyond first segment usually

Ww with little erect hair.

~ apiform—body form of workers of Apis mellifera [Fig. 507]. That is, more robust than

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
~ andreniform and more slender than euceriform.

~ bombiform—body form of Bombus [Figs. 508 and 509]. Like anthophoriform but metasoma

~ with much erect hair, like mesosoma.

w epeoliform—body form of Epeolus or Triepeolus [Fig. 493]. Somewhat more robust than

vu Nomada but nonetheless wasplike parasitic bees; scopa absent; body often with areas of short,
pale pubescence forming a conspicuous pattern.

Y euceriform—body form of Melissodes [Figs. 481 and 482]. Similar to anthophoriform but

v somewhat less robust.

~ heriadiform—body form of Hoplitis [Fig. 471], Heriades [Figs. 469 and 470], or Megachile

~ (Chelostomoides) [Fig. 465]. Similar to megachiliform but more slender, metasoma parallel

oe sided.

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
oe sided.

~ hylaeiform—body form of Hylaeus [Fig. 420]. Slender, hairs inconspicuous without

~ magnification, scopa inconspicuous or absent.

- megachiliform—body form of Megachile (Megachile) [Figs. 463 and 464], Osmia [Fig. 472], or
Dianthidium [Fig. 457]. Heavy body, thick head, metasoma rather wide, not parallel sided.

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
nomadiform—body form of Nomada [Figs. 498 and 499]. Slender, wasplike, not noticeably
hairy, often with yellow or red markings or entirely red or yellow; scopa absent. ~
—
trigoniform—body form of Trigona [Fig. 519] and its relatives. Metasoma small or slender; J
body not conspicuously hairy, that is, hairs short and metasoma usually shiny. ”
Many bees do not fall unequivocally into one of the above categories. Much of a ~
specimen's appearance depends on how full the crop was when the specimen was killed, how wy
much the metasoma has telescoped in drying, and so forth. Nonetheless, we think that these wy
terms may be useful to give an idea of the characteristic aspect of a genus.
CONTENT OF THE NOTES. The notes and keys give characteristics of species within our area, ~

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
which is America north of the Colombia-Panama border, including the Antilles (i.e., North VY
America). Extralimital species may not agree with all characters listed. Under each family, taxa
are arranged according to Table 2-1, which provides a complete classification at the family, ~
subfamily, tribal, and generic levels. For more detailed information on each genus as well as baad
additional taxonomic notes on the subgenera, see Michener (2007). ww
In most bees the integument is black. If it is extensively colored otherwise (e.g., red,
yellow, or metallic blue or green), it is noted. Hairiness, when mentioned, refers to long hairs, ~
giving a more robust and fuzzy aspect, unless otherwise indicated. ~
For each genus, after listing some morphological characteristics, the notes give a Y

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
subjective idea of abundance, based on collecting experience. In Table 2-1 we provide an UY
estimate of the number of species in our area (Canada, United States, Mexico, Guatemala,
Belize, E] Salvador, Honduras, Nicaragua, Costa Rica, Panama, and the Greater and Lesser ~
Antilles) based on information provided in Ascher and Pickering 2020 (Discover Life: bad
https://www.discoverlife.org/mp/20q?search=A poidea [note version and date in final draft]). ww
Next, the notes indicate the range (and sometimes habitat) of the genus within our area,
including a rough indication of the more extensive neotropical range, if applicable, followed by a ~
parenthetical notation if the range is more extensive—for example, holarctic or cosmopolitan. ~

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
The word Mesoamerica as used here means Mexico and Central America, including Panama. Ww
The word tropical is frequently used and refers to lowland areas, usually moist or mesic, in UY
Mesoamerica. Additional details on the biogeography of each genus can be found in Michener
(2007). ~
Most bees are solitary, that is, with one female per nest, and the nests are burrows in the ~
ground made by the bees (Danforth et al. 2019). Sometimes nests occur in large and dense ww
aggregations, but the bees are nonetheless considered solitary. Notation is made of genera that
include some species or populations that are social, either cooperatively breeding or eusocial (as ~
defined in Danforth et al. 2019) or that nest in different sites or substrates. Nests are unknown for bad

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Text Content:
certain genera. A review of known immature stages was made by McGinley (1989) but larval w
bees from additional genera have since been described by Rozen and others. w
Many groups of solitary bees are host-plant specialists (also referred to as “oligolectic”
bees), meaning they visit a small group of closely related host-plants for pollen. For these asl
specialist groups we list the likely host-plant genera and families upon which they specialize. For ~
“oil bees”, bees that collect floral oils for brood cell lining and pollen provisions, we also list the ww

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Image Description: Fig. 2 in the manuscript by John I Huber, published in MMD, focuses on the anatomical features of the head capsule in a specified insect species. The figure provides a detailed illustration of the malar area, which is defined as the space between the eye and the mandible. The malar area's significance lies in its use for taxonomic differentiation, as its length is measured as the shortest distance from the eye to the base of the mandible. Additionally, the figure highlights the foveae on the face and the sides of the second metasomal tergum (T2). These foveae are depicted as shallow depressions and are typically black in color, serving as critical identifiers for species classification. This visual representation aids in understanding the spatial relationships and morphological characteristics critical for scientific and educational purposes in entomology.

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Image Description: Figure 3 from the manuscript by John I Huber in the journal MMD focuses on the anatomical features of the bee's head, particularly the genal area and the preoccipital ridge. This figure provides a detailed illustration of the bee's head highlighting the genal area, which is located behind the eye and in front of the preoccipital ridge. The preoccipital ridge itself is depicted as a prominent structure encircling the posterior part of the head, characterized by its concavity and sometimes featuring a preoccipital carina, which is a ridge found on the preoccipital ridge. Additionally, the figure includes a depiction of the proboscidial fossa, a significant groove on the underside of the head where the proboscis retracts. This visual representation is crucial for understanding the spatial relationships and morphological details of these components, which are essential for studies related to bee anatomy and physiology. The clear labeling and distinct illustration of each part make this figure a valuable resource for researchers focusing on entomological and anatomical studies of bees.

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Image Description: Figure 4, sourced from MMD and authored by John I Huber, focuses on the anatomical details of the malar area in an insect head capsule. This figure is pivotal for understanding the spatial relationship between the eye and the mandible of the insect, highlighting the shortest distance from the eye to the mandible and the width of the base of the mandible. Additionally, it illustrates the genal area, which is located behind the eye and in front of the preoccipital ridge. The figure effectively delineates the boundaries and features of these areas, crucial for studies in entomology related to insect head morphology. The clear labeling and detailed depiction serve as a valuable reference for identifying and comparing these anatomical features across different insect species.

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Image Description: Fig. 5, sourced from MMD and authored by John I Huber, illustrates the detailed anatomy of bee mandibles, focusing on their structural components as per the naming conventions of Michener and Fraser (1978). This figure is central to understanding the functional morphology of bee mouthparts, specifically highlighting the mandibles used for chewing. Key labeled components include the preapical teeth and various other mandibular structures, each annotated clearly to show their relative positions and interactions. These components are crucial for the bees' ability to process food materials, playing a significant role in their feeding mechanism which involves both lapping and sucking nectar. The diagram serves as an essential reference for entomologists and researchers studying hymenopteran mouthpart mechanics and their evolutionary adaptations.

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Image Description: Fig. 6, sourced from MMD and authored by John I. Huber, illustrates the specialized structure of bee mouthparts, focusing particularly on the labial palpus. This figure is essential for understanding the morphological differences in the labial palpus among various bee families. It specifically highlights the first two segments of the labial palpus, which are depicted as elongated, flattened, and sheath-like, contrasting sharply with the shorter, more typical last two segments. This configuration is significant as it demonstrates adaptation in the feeding mechanism of bees, supporting efficient nectar and pollen collection. The detailed labeling and differentiation in the figure provide a clear visual comparison, aiding in the identification and study of bee species based on mouthpart morphology. This figure is a key reference for entomologists and researchers studying the functional anatomy and evolutionary biology of bees.

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Image Description: Figure 7, as presented in the Molecular and Morphological Diversity (MMD) publication by John I. Huber, focuses on the detailed anatomy of bee mouthparts, specifically highlighting the maxillary palpus and the clypeus. This figure is essential for understanding the morphological variations and functional aspects of these components. The maxillary palpus, depicted with six distinct segments, plays a crucial role in sensory functions, allowing bees to taste and manipulate their environment. The clypeus, shown with a strongly irregular rugosopunctate texture, is significant for its protective role and its involvement in the structural integrity of the head. This figure serves as a critical reference for entomologists and researchers studying the intricate structures and evolutionary adaptations of bee mouthparts.

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.

This figure is central to understanding the functional morphology of bee feeding mechanisms. It illustrates a six-segmented maxillary palpus, each segment distinctly labeled and differentiated by size and shape, which highlights its articulation and potential for movement. Adjacent to the maxillary palpus, the figure also shows the clypeus characterized by a strongly irregular rugosopunctate texture, providing insights into the tactile interfaces of the bee's mouthparts. The detailed labeling and clear depiction serve as a crucial reference for entomologists studying the anatomical precision of bee feeding apparatus and its evolutionary adaptations. This figure encapsulates key anatomical features that are essential for grasping the mechanical and sensory capabilities of bee mouthparts.

Title: MMD

The figure is a close-up view highlighting the maxillary palpus, which is notably segmented into six parts, and the clypeus, characterized by its strongly irregular rugosopunctate texture. These components are crucial for understanding the feeding mechanics and sensory capabilities of bees. The maxillary palpus, with its multiple segments, suggests flexibility and potential for fine sensory functions, while the textured clypeus may play a role in protection and sensory input. Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Image Description: Figure 8, sourced from MMD and authored by John I Huber, illustrates the unique morphology of the glossa and labial palpus in the Colletidae family of bees, contrasting with other bee families. This figure is pivotal for understanding the structural adaptations in bee mouthparts, specifically focusing on the Colletidae compared to long-tongued bees such as Apidae and Megachilidae. The glossa in Colletidae is depicted as broader and less elongate than in other families, which typically feature a slender and elongate glossa. Additionally, the labial palpal segments in Colletidae are shown as similar and cylindrical, which contrasts with the varying segment morphology seen in other bee families where the first two segments can be distinctly different. This figure effectively highlights the evolutionary diversification in mouthpart structures among different bee families, emphasizing the functional and ecological implications of these variations.

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Image Description: Figure 9, sourced from MMD and authored by John I Huber, illustrates the detailed anatomy of bee mouthparts, specifically focusing on the proboscis mechanism. This figure is crucial for understanding how bees ingest nectar and other liquids, a key aspect of their feeding behavior and ecological role. The diagram clearly labels and highlights several critical components: the glossa, which is the central tongue-like structure used for sucking up nectar; the labial palps, which help in manipulating the proboscis; and the maxillae, which support the glossa and contain sensory hairs. Each component is meticulously detailed to show its position and interaction with other parts of the proboscis, emphasizing the complex and specialized nature of bee mouthparts. This figure is essential for entomologists and biologists studying insect anatomy and feeding mechanisms.

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Image Description: Fig. 10 from the manuscript by John I Huber in MMD illustrates the distinct sexual dimorphism in antennal segments of bees, focusing on the differences between males and females. The figure provides a detailed visual comparison, highlighting that males possess 13 antennal segments, whereas females have 12. This key difference is annotated clearly in the image, with each segment numbered sequentially for clarity. Additionally, the figure subtly emphasizes the variation in the protrusion of the antennae in relation to the compound eyes, quantified as 0.5 to 0.8 times the eye width, which is depicted with precise measurements from the anterior tangent of the compound eye. This measurement is crucial for understanding the spatial arrangement and physical morphology of these insects, providing insights into their anatomical adaptations and identification. The figure is essential for entomologists and researchers focusing on insect morphology and taxonomy, offering a clear, visual differentiation between genders in bee species.

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Image Description: Fig. 11 from the source MMD, authored by John I Huber, focuses on the anatomical features of the mesosoma in bees. This figure is crucial for understanding the structural adaptations that facilitate the movement and functionality of bees, particularly in their burrowing behaviors. The key labeled components in Fig. 11 include the basitibial plate and the mandible with and without a deep groove. The basitibial plate, located on the outer side of the base of the hind tibia, is highlighted for its presumed role in providing support as bees navigate their burrows. Additionally, the figure contrasts mandibles with and without a deep diagonal groove running across the mandibular base to the acetabulum, illustrating a significant morphological variation that may influence the bee's feeding or digging capabilities. These features are essential for taxonomic differentiation and understanding the ecological adaptations of various bee species.

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Image Description: Fig. 11, sourced from MMD and authored by John I Huber, focuses on the anatomical features of the mesosoma in bees, particularly highlighting the structure and significance of tibial spurs and the basitibial plate. The figure meticulously illustrates the mesosoma, a central body segment of bees which plays a crucial role in mobility and muscle attachment. Key labeled components include the tibial spurs, which are sharp, apical projections on the tibia, vital for identification and classification in bee taxonomy. Additionally, the basitibial plate, located on the outer side of the hind tibia, is depicted, emphasizing its presumed function in providing support as bees navigate their burrows. This figure serves as a detailed visual reference for understanding specific morphological traits that are critical for the study of bee anatomy and behavior.

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Image Description: Fig. 11, sourced from MMD and authored by John I Huber, focuses on the anatomical features of the mesosoma in bees, highlighting its significance in bee taxonomy and identification. The figure prominently displays the mesosoma, a central body segment in bees that connects the head and the abdomen, crucial for muscle attachment and movement. Key labeled components include the basitibial plate and tibial spurs. The basitibial plate, located on the outer side of the base of the hind tibia, is noted for its role in providing support as bees navigate their burrows. Tibial spurs, described as sharp, apical projections on the tibia, are small but critical for identification, as their structure varies significantly among different bee families. This figure serves as an essential reference for entomologists and researchers studying bee morphology and systematics.

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Image Description: Fig. 12, sourced from MMD and authored by John I Huber, illustrates the anatomical structure of the mesosoma in bees, focusing on the arolium and pygidial plate. This figure is pivotal for understanding variations in these structures across different bee taxa. The arolium, depicted between the tarsal claws, is a key feature for identifying certain bee families; it is shown as a pad-like protrusion that is absent in some groups like Megachile and Euglossini. Additionally, the pygidial plate, which is strongly tapering and bluntly pointed at the apex, is another critical component highlighted in this figure. This plate is also noted for its strong elevation along the midline, providing a distinct morphological trait useful for taxonomic differentiation in bees. The clear labeling and detailed depiction of these structures make Fig. 12 an essential reference for entomologists studying bee taxonomy and morphology.

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Image Description: Figure 13, sourced from MMD and authored by John I Huber, illustrates the anatomical structure of the mesosoma in bees, focusing on the propodeum and its subdivisions. This figure is crucial for understanding the unique morphological adaptations in the Apocrita suborder, particularly in bees. The key labeled components include the basal area and the declivous posterior surface of the propodeum. The basal area is depicted as a more or less horizontal region at the base of the propodeum, clearly demarcated by a sharp line or carina from the declivous posterior surface, which is inclined downward. This detailed visualization aids in distinguishing the mesosoma from the metasoma, highlighting the propodeum's role as a transitional segment between these major body regions. This figure is essential for entomologists and biologists studying hymenopteran anatomy and the specific structural characteristics of bees.

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Image Description: Fig. 14, sourced from MMD and authored by John I Huber, visually details the dorsal view of the mesothorax in bees, highlighting its division into four distinct sclerites. This figure is critical for understanding the anatomical structure of bees, specifically focusing on the mesothorax which supports the wings and legs. The key labeled components include the scutum and the scutellum, along with paired sclerites that are essential for the attachment and function of the bee’s wings. The illustration provides a clear representation of these components, emphasizing their relative positions and sizes, which are crucial for the taxonomy and identification of different bee species. This figure serves as an important educational tool for entomologists and researchers studying bee anatomy and physiology.

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Image Description: Fig. 15, sourced from MMD and authored by John I Huber, illustrates the wing structure of a bee using a modified Comstock and Needham system for vein labeling. The figure focuses on the detailed anatomy of the bee's wing, highlighting the arrangement and homologies of the veins, which are crucial for identifying species-specific characteristics and understanding aerodynamic properties. Key labeled components include major veins such as the costa, subcosta, radius, media, cubitus, and anal veins. The figure also labels the pterostigma, referred to here simply as "stigma," which is a thickened, often pigmented area on the leading edge of the wing that aids in flight stability. Additionally, the jugal and vannal lobes of the hind wing are shown, measured from the wing base to the apex, indicating their role in wing folding and maneuverability. This detailed depiction provides essential insights into the functional morphology and taxonomy of bee wings.

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Image Description: Fig. 16, sourced from MMD and authored by John I Huber, illustrates the wing venation patterns of bees using a modified Comstock and Needham system. This figure is essential for understanding the homologies of wing veins, which are not very clear without such detailed depiction. The key labeled components in the figure include various veins like the marginal cell (M), radial sector (Rs), and medial vein (Mv). These components are crucial for identifying and differentiating between different bee families based on their wing structures. The figure effectively highlights the distinctive vein arrangements that are characteristic of specific bee groups, aiding in the taxonomic classification and study of bee biodiversity. This detailed yet concise representation provides a clear visual reference for researchers studying entomology and the evolutionary biology of bees.

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Image Description: Fig. 17, sourced from MMD and authored by John I Huber, illustrates the specific anatomical features of bee wing venation, focusing on the identification and significance of three veins that resemble crossveins. This figure is essential for understanding bee taxonomy and differentiating between species based on wing structures. The key labeled components in the figure include the second abscissa of the radius (2r), the second radial sector (Rs+M), and the medial vein (M+Cu). Each of these veins plays a critical role in the structural integrity and aerodynamic functionality of the bee's wing, and their identification helps in the accurate classification and study of various bee species. The clear labeling and differentiation of these veins provide a valuable reference for entomologists and researchers studying the morphological variations within bee families.

Title: MMD

This measurement is crucial for understanding the wing morphology which plays a significant role in the taxonomy and identification of different bee families. The depiction clearly labels the second abscissa of Rs, a vein that resembles a crossvein, further aiding in the detailed study of wing venation patterns critical for entomological research. This visual representation serves as a valuable reference for entomologists and taxonomists specializing in bee classification.

Title: MMD

The graduli, marked as transverse lines across the terga, are crucial for identifying the boundaries of each segment. The pygidial plate, typically found in the last visible segment of the metasoma, is depicted as a flat, sometimes carinated structure, which can vary in appearance but is essential for species identification and sexual differentiation in bees. This figure serves as a critical reference for entomologists and biologists studying bee morphology and taxonomy, providing clear visual distinctions essential for accurate identification and understanding of bee anatomy.

Title: MMD

Title: MMD

Image Description: Fig. 22, sourced from MMD and authored by John I Huber, illustrates the anatomical features of the hind tibia in Apidae, focusing on the corbicula. This figure is pivotal for understanding the unique structural adaptations in the hind legs of highly social bees, including queens, and in the genus Hylaeus. The corbicula, a key labeled component in the figure, is depicted on the outer surface of the hind tibia, contrary to previous assumptions that placed it on the anterior surface. This specialized structure serves as a pollen basket, crucial for pollen collection and transportation, highlighting its evolutionary significance in bee species that exhibit advanced social behaviors. The clarity of this depiction aids in distinguishing the corbicula's exact position and structure, which is essential for taxonomic and functional studies in apidology.

These carinae are significant as they do not converge with the anterior carina or the external sagittal ridge, highlighting their unique alignment and structural positioning. Title: MMD

Image Description: Figure 29 from the manuscript by John I Huber in MMD illustrates the specialized anatomical structure of a parasitic wasp's ovipositor, specifically focusing on its adaptation for host penetration. The figure provides a detailed view of the ovipositor's tip, which is notably extended beyond the lateral process and morphs into a broad, ventrally setose plate. This adaptation is critical for the wasp's reproductive success, as it enhances the ability to deposit eggs into host organisms effectively. Key components labeled in the figure include the elongated ovipositor shaft, the lateral process, and the setose plate, each highlighted to emphasize their functional roles in host interaction and egg placement. This detailed anatomical depiction aids in understanding the evolutionary modifications in parasitic wasps that optimize their reproductive strategies.

Title: MMD

The figure includes detailed labeling of these veins to highlight their comparative underdevelopment. Key components such as the leading edge of the wing, the location of the cubital veins, and the point where the second recurrent vein should typically emerge are clearly marked. Image Description: Figure 115 from the manuscript by John I Huber in MMD illustrates the detailed anatomy of the hind wing of a Melitta bee, focusing on the jugal and vannal lobes. The diagram is annotated to show the precise structure and relative proportions of these lobes, providing essential insights into their functional and evolutionary significance. The jugal lobe, in particular, is emphasized due to its length and potential role in flight dynamics and control. This figure serves as a valuable resource for entomologists and evolutionary biologists studying wing morphology variations within bee species and their ecological adaptations.

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Image Description: Figure 116 from the manuscript by John I Huber in the Molecular Microbial Diversity (MMD) journal depicts the anatomical differentiation of the scopa in female bees, specifically focusing on its location on the hind tibia rather than on the basal segments of the leg. This figure is crucial for understanding the morphological adaptations related to pollen collection in bees. The key labeled components include the hind tibia, highlighted to show the dense, brush-like structure of the scopa, and the basal segments of the leg, which are indicated without scopa. This contrast underscores the evolutionary specialization in certain bee species, facilitating efficient pollen transport. The figure serves as a comparative tool, illustrating significant evolutionary traits that contribute to the ecological roles of these pollinators.

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Image Description: Fig. 117, sourced from MMD and authored by John I Huber, illustrates the anatomical adaptations of a parasitic bee's hind leg, specifically focusing on the absence of a scopa and the development of other features. The figure highlights the hind femur and trochanter, showing the presence of a well-developed floccus and modifications to the basitarsus. The floccus, depicted as a long, curved, and plumose structure, is significant for its role in closing the basal end of the femoro-oral corbicula, a specialized structure for carrying pollen in non-parasitic bees. This adaptation is crucial for the bee's interaction with host species and environments where direct pollen collection is not necessary. Additionally, the hind basitarsus is shown to be more than half the length of the hind tibia, a feature that supports the bee's mobility and stability during flight and when interacting with host plants. This detailed visualization serves to enhance understanding of morphological specialization in parasitic bees, emphasizing evolutionary adaptations that facilitate their unique ecological niches.

The figure clearly labels the lacinia as a small, hairy lobe located on the anterior face of the labiomaxillary tube. This specific adaptation is significant as it may suggest a specialized feeding or sensory function within the insect's ecology. The diagram is essential for understanding the morphological variations within this group and provides a detailed visual reference for comparative anatomical studies.

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Image Description: Figure 414 from the source MMD, authored by John I Huber, illustrates the anatomical structure of a lobe projecting behind the labiomaxillary tube, which is the basal part of the proboscis in certain insect species. The figure provides a detailed view of the lobe, emphasizing its position relative to the labiomaxillary tube and highlighting its morphological features. Key labeled components include the lobe itself, identified for its unique shape and location, and the labiomaxillary tube, marked to show its foundational role in the structure of the proboscis. This figure is essential for understanding the physical relationships and functional anatomy of these components in the context of insect feeding mechanisms. The depiction aids in visualizing how the lobe supports or interacts with the labiomaxillary tube, contributing to the efficiency of the proboscis in nutrient uptake.

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Image Description: Figure 415 from the source MMD, authored by John I Huber, illustrates the anatomical structure of a lorum, a specific feature in insect morphology. The figure provides a detailed view of the lorum, which is depicted as either V-shaped or Y-shaped. This key labeled component is significant as it highlights variations in the lorum's structure, which can be crucial for the identification and classification of different insect species. The diagram focuses on the lorum’s position relative to other facial structures, emphasizing its role and location in the insect head anatomy. This clear and focused depiction aids in understanding the morphological differences and similarities among species, serving as an essential reference for entomologists and researchers studying insect taxonomy and phylogeny.

Title: MMD
Author: Danforth, Bryan, et al.
Image Description: Figure 416, sourced from MMD and authored by John I Huber, illustrates the anatomical features of the glossa in the context of bee morphology, specifically focusing on the Colletidae family. The figure effectively highlights the pointed structure of the glossa, contrasting it with other morphological variations such as truncate, emarginate, or bilobed glossae. Key labeled components include the glossa itself, which is central to the figure, detailed to show its pointed tip which is significant for its role in nectar collection and pollen manipulation in bees. Additionally, the figure depicts the mentum and the lorum, which are shown without the formation of a projecting lobe behind the labiomaxillary tube, a characteristic feature distinguishing certain bee families. This detailed visualization aids in understanding the functional morphology of bee mouthparts, emphasizing the specialization in the feeding and foraging behaviors of the Colletidae.

Title: Hymenoptera of the World
Author: Charles D. Michener
Text Content:
Chapter3 3S
John T. Huber and Mict
General com

This guide is intended to familiarize the reader
with the families of Hymenoptera, not hymen-
opteran morphology. We therefore attempt to use
the simplest acceptable terms for structures. Terms Gi
used in the keys are defined and illustrated in the
glossary. A brief overview of hymenopteran
morphology, accompanied by labeled drawings of
bodies and wings representing some major groups
of Hymenoptera, is given to orient the reader and .
put into perspective many of the terms used. Gi

Title: Hymenoptera of the World
Author: Charles D. Michener
Text Content:
When the reader goes beyond this guide to
identify specimens to the level of genus or species, a
plethora of other, often synonymous, morphological
terms will be encountered. In part, this occurs
because over many years various terms have been
replaced by more exact or more generalized terms
and different terms have been applied to
homologous structures in various groups.

Consequently, any given structure may have several He

names applied to it, and one term may apply to

several distinct structures. This confusion is

nowhere more apparent than in names applied to

the wing veins, where several major systems are

used.

Title: Hymenoptera of the World
Author: Charles D. Michener
Text Content:
used.

It is beyond the scope of this guide to define all M
terms as they have been applied to structures within
Hymenoptera. The following annotated list of
references will help the interested reader.

Bohart, R.M., and A.S. Menke. 1976. Sphecid wasps
of the world: a generic revision. University of
California Press, Berkeley, California, USA. ix + Ni
695 pp.

The morphology chapter, especially the

sections on wing venation and the lists of

synonyms for various terms, is useful to all who

work on aculeate Hymenoptera.

Brothers, D.J. 1975. Phylogeny and classification of Ri
the aculeate Hymenoptera, with special
reference to Mutillidae. University of Kansas
Science Bulletin 50:483—648.

Includes the first cladistic analysis of Aculeata,

with a detailed discussion of characters.

Title: Hymenoptera of the World
Author: Charles D. Michener
Text Content:
Boutek, Z. 1988. Australasian Chalcidoidea
(Hymenoptera): a biosystematic revision of R
genera of fourteen families, with a
reclassification of species. C.A.B. International,
Wallingford, England, 832 pp.

tructure

ae! J. Sharkey

ments
Includes a detailed discussion of terms used in
chalcidoid taxonomy.

suld, I., and B. Bolton, eds. 1988. The
Hymenoptera. Oxford University Press,
Oxford, England. xi + 332 pp.
Includes a chapter on the morphology of
Hymenoptera.

bson, G.A.P. 1985. Some pro- and mesothoracic
structures important for phylogenetic analysis
of Hymenoptera, with a review of terms for the
structures. Canadian Entomologist
117:1395—1443.
A review and reinterpretation of thoracic
structure and a discussion of synonymous terms
applied to them.

Title: Hymenoptera of the World
Author: Charles D. Michener
Text Content:
jlldobler, B., and E.O. Wilson. 1990. The ants.
The Belknap Press of Harvard University Press,
Cambridge, Massachusetts, USA. 732 pp.

ants.

ichener, C.D. 1944. Comparative external

82:151—326.

chols, S.W,, comp. 1989. The Torre-Bueno

Entomological Society, New York, New York,
USA. 840 pp.
The most comprehensive reference book in
English for entomological terms.

Title: Hymenoptera of the World
Author: Charles D. Michener
Text Content:
chards, O.W. 1977. Hymenoptera: introduction
and key to families. Second edition. Handbooks

A detailed overview of hymenopteran

mquist, F., and G. Nordlander. 1989. Skeletal

13

Title: Hymenoptera of the World
Author: Charles D. Michener
Text Content:
A detailed account of one species, including a
discussion of its structure and terms used in
relation to other Hymenoptera.

Ross, H.H. 1937. A generic classification of the
Nearctic sawflies (Hymenoptera, Symphyta).
Illinois biological monographs 15(2). 173 pp.
A reference for sawfly morphology.

morphology. McGraw-Hill, New York, New
York, USA. ix + 667 pp.

A general work on insect morphology.
Townes, H.K. 1969. The genera of Ichneumonidae,

Part I. Memoirs of the American

Entomological Institute. Number 11. America
